item.title: Why Is Dot Product Defined and Calculated That Way
item.description: Suppose we have: $$\vec{a} = \begin{vmatrix} a_x \\ a_y \end{vmatrix}$$ $$\vec{b} = \begin{bmatrix} b_x \\ b_y \end{bmatrix}$$ I am wondering why $\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b} = a_x b_x + a_y b_y$. Let’s prove this by having a concrete example: $$\vec{a} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}$$ $$\vec{b} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}$$ If you are familiar with linear algebra, you’ll know that $$\vec{a}\cdot \vec{b} = ||\vec{a}||\cdot ||\vec{b}|| \cdot \cos \theta$$
